Fields.DialogueText: We ought to make course to here, Capitano. I wager that we should be to Livorno within two hours if we keep going.
I hope we don't get sidetracked this time. We're kind of behind schedule.
Nonsense, Capitano. I think we should be alright. I already sent a telegram to the coast guard.

Fields.MenuText: So, you sent a telegram to yourself?
What did they reply with?
Livorno is patient, unlike Cagliari.

Fields.DialogueText: *Snort!* Capitano... I may be named for the Carabinieri, but I am by no means one. If I had sent a telegram to myself, that would've been a poem! I think I'll write a letter to Livorno's harbormaster.
"It's no trouble, just don't bring trouble with you!" Do I really have that much of a reputation already? Hm, maybe I should write something better? The harbormaster deserves a redraft of my message.
Don't remind me, they got really upset at us for arriving a minute late. Then again, uniformity and punctuality breeds good men. I should write on that! That'll turn the harbormaster's head.
If you want to write, now's as good a time as any. We have two hours, don't we?
Do you have a good ink pen, Capitano? I feel this one should warrant it.
I know you write sometimes, but going all out for this? It's just a redraft.
Redrafts are important, Capitano. A few key differences in words can mean so much. I'm going to write a letter that may contain a double meaning. Speaking of, do you know any other words for "valor?"
Glory?
Stardom?
Fame?
Fortune?
Holmes.
Moriarty!
(The Captain and Carabinieri share a hearty laugh.)
With any luck, they'll laugh as much as we did.
I hope so. And-- *SMACK* Ow... That made me hit my desk...
I'll take care of it later, Capitano, I promise. For now, though, I think a warm up is in order.
Agreed.
@BATTLE
Livorno sure is lively. Rather too much so, considering what we had to deal with in getting here.
I still owe you some gelato, Cara. You were definitely right.
After we meet with the harbormaster, I'd be glad to share mine with you.
Devilish. I may just get my own cone.
Cones? Ahahahaha! No, no, Capitano. Here we eat ice cream in dishes.
That's a bit classy. Do they at least come in bigger sizes? I know Americans tend to get them big, too.
Is that true? That sounds a bit outlandish. If they do that over there, who knows what else they might have?

Fields.MenuText: Root beer floats.
They made "Sundaes." Ice cream with everything.
Well, it's served basically everywhere stateside.

Fields.DialogueText: Root beer floats? Mixing cream with drinks is nothing new, but with alcohol?
Everything!? I can't imagine the flavor that must have. Who would do something so reckless? Next thing they'll do is they'll put cake inside it! That... doesn't sound too bad, actually.
Don't they have parlors for them? You seriously aren't implying that they're serving them in concert halls? That'll ruin the music! Still, I am glad more people know about it.
Do you have a sweet tooth, Cara?
Only for gelato. The quality that it's prepared with is nothing short of heavenly. Perfect for a hot summer's day.
Isn't it? Helps that Livorno is beautiful.
Isn't it, though? A lesser known corner of Italia, but proud all the same. It's simply exquisite.
It certainly looks and plays the part, however, we didn't come here for just sightseeing. Isn't the harbormaster's office close to here?
I believe it's up ahead and to the left. Maybe we'll--
Ah! Run! She-devils! They're here! Get away!!!
Capitano?
What a welcome wagon! Let's return the favor and put on a good show for the harbormaster.
Agreed. I might be able to do some target practice while I'm at it!
@BATTLE
It's soda, not beer.
Better. We have cream soda here as well. Delicious...
Well, I've had worse meetings...
Don't be so down, Capitano. If you were to ask me, I'd say the harbormaster was more cross at the fact that Morganas were allowed to come that close.
As much as I don't want to say that's our fault, it is our fault.
We are responsible for exterminating the Morganas and keeping the people safe, but the garrisons near the upper landings could've at least tried to fire on them.
Hindsight. At least we got what we came for.
Livorno's doing well, Il Duce's men are in line, and the city is experiencing a nice boom. This city was destined for a rise.
From Cicero to Medici, and now Il Duce. Fortunately for us, the city is more than just looks.
They've really gone all out with the weapons budget here. Livorno deserves it, but I can't shake a certain feeling about Italia right now.

Fields.MenuText: Is it the cigarette smoke?
A detective's sixth sense is usually never wrong.
Think they can cut us in on the arsenal?

Fields.DialogueText: No, but I appreciate you being considerate of me, Capitano. Hmhm! I don't know what to call this feeling. Anxiety, perhaps? Paranoia? Something just feels off.
True, though it's gotten Holmes into more trouble. Then again, Miss Marple uses it to the greatest effect in "The Murder At The Vicarage." Maybe I'm confused about something else?
I'll make inquiries, Capitano, but I don't think they've assembled all this just to give it away.
If you want, I can talk with the other captains stationed around here. Maybe they've seen things?
It could be just a hunch, Capitano. I just... H-Hmm...
Cara, are you alright?
N-No. Forgive me, Capitano, I remembered something painful and I wouldn't like to talk about it.
Hey, at least you were honest about it, Cara. That's all I ask. If you aren't comfortable with it, you don't need to share. We're a team, remember?
Si, Capitano. I promise, you can count on me!
I may need to count on you in the near future. The radar's picking up some Morganas just south of here.
I knew something wasn't right.
"Instinct is a marvelous thing."
Hmhmhahaha! "It can be neither explained, nor ignored!" And I won't ignore these Morganas!
@BATTLE
Are you ready, Capitano?
So all I have to do is press this button here?
Si, si. When I'm ready, I'll shout "pull" and then you press the button.
Of course. Are you ready?
Indeed, Capitano. Now, watch closely! Let's see, here! *CLICK* Under here... *CHUNK* and for the finale. *CHUCK-CHUCK* Wonderful.
You assembled that rifle from nothing in 10 seconds... Not even a trained soldier can do it in 15! Impressive!
Well, Capitano, I believe I have a bit of an unfair advantage. My Carcano is a bit special. It can be easily worked on, but that's neither here nor there; let's get to practicing. And... pull!
Alright, press this button...
*RRRRRR...* *FWOOMP* *FWOOMP* *FWOOMP*
Uno. *P-TAO* *CLINK* *CHUCK-CHUCK* Due. *P-TAO* *CLINK* *CHUCK-CHUCK* Tre. *P-TAO* *CLINK* *CHUCK-CHUCK* Marvelous!
I'll say. Two of those went flying off to the right! Did you set this thing up to dispense three at a time?
Si, Capitano. The Carcano only holds six shots, much like a revolver. I had it shoot out in threes so that I could better react to moving targets when they appeared.

Fields.MenuText: Now that's some good optics.
You shoot really well. I could barely see the bolt!
A detective with a sharp eye.

Fields.DialogueText: Pffft... Hmhmhmhahahaha! Come now, Capitano! That's horrible! Nera would hit you for that one... You are right, though - my aim has improved greatly with this addition.
Many say that the Carcano is rather bad when compared to, say, a Kar. For me, Capitano, I changed a few things around; that bolt is just one of those things. Same with that machine!
That's what made Moriarty so terrifying. By using mathematics, he could calculate the trajectory of something from space alone. I wager I could figure the speed of a clay pigeon if I wanted to!
With such attention to detail, to boot! I must say, I'm impressed.
Oh, please, Capitano. I'm impressed with you, as well. You looked beyond what the others said and are still helping me learn more. Did you know I had to do this whole shooting thing myself?
You... did? That sounds dangerous, but I understand. After all, you work better as a team.
It's a lot easier than it would appear, Capitano, and I agree. I don't think of myself as a detective, but I'm glad you're my capitano.
I could say the same of-- Huh? Do you hear that?
Ah! That's your telegraph, Capitano! Someone must be sending an important message if it's this time of day. Let's move!
Yeah let's-- Woah! *FWIP*
Huph! *CATCH* Are you alright, Capitano? I wasn't expecting a Morgana to sideswipe me like that! I should've been able to sense them...
Focus can be diverted. I think it's time we get back on track and hit some live targets.
Good practice...
@BATTLE
A fault in the radar? That's... unfortunate.
I'm having some experts look at you now. They should have you in working order soon. I'm sorry, Cara. That's my fault.
It's nothing, Capitano. I should've trusted my senses!
Scusi, Capitano, Signorina Carabiniere. I've come bearing an important letter.
Ah! Corsaca! It's good to see you. Are you in better spirits than earlier? I heard about-- wait, did you say a letter?
I am fantastic, thank you for asking. It's always a pleasure to see you, Signorina.
I told you, Corsaca, you can just call me Cara. I won't hold it against you!
Neither will I.
Ahaha! At last, a capitano who knows how to joke around, too... A-Ahem! My apologies, I bring a letter, yes. It's from Amerigo Vespucci.
Amerigo Vespucci? You mean that training ship that's a bit of an adventurer?
The very same.

Fields.MenuText: What... What is this cursive?
A letter? That's kind of old-fashioned.
Even a wax seal...

Fields.DialogueText: Oh! That's how Vespucci always writes, Capitano. Haven't you met her? I tell you, her handwriting could easily belong in a museum. I wonder what she wrote us for?
You should expect nothing less from Vespucci. The last time I tried to teach her how to send a telegram, she got frustrated. But a letter is certainly nothing short of classy.
Oho! You should watch out, Capitano. When she seals her letters with wax, it's of grave importance. Still, why send it to us and not Il Duce, or the INPF?
Well, let's see here... Whatever it is, it's addressed to you, Cara.
Well, let me read... Hm. Ah, that's the Vespucci I know, always addressing me as "my esteemed Carabinieri." Hm... Hm... It appears Naples is in trouble. The military and people need our help.
A situation in Naples? The telegram earlier did mention it. They said it wasn't our concern. Something tells me they're wrong.
They are. Vespucci says that she's been receiving distress transmissions, but she's helping out with an assault. She's asking me to go in her stead and sort it out. What do you make of it, Capitano?
I say we move. We're not doing anything right now other than patrolling.
Our goal was to meet the harbormaster and get a report, then "remain alert." I believe this qualifies as an alert.
That's more than an alert - those people are in danger! What if the Morganas get to them first!?
I assure you, I won't let them touch the people of Italia. I cannot guarantee, however, that they won't rough us up a bit now if we don't hurry.
Ah. The radar's fixed. Battle stations, everyone.
@BATTLE
We're approaching Naples now. I'm sensing Morganas about, but there aren't as many as Vespucci suggested in her letter...
They're still surrounding the port, and that's troublesome enough. Do you think you can take your shots now?
Say the word, partner.
Partner?
You don't mind the nickname, do you, Capitano?
I kind of like it, but please use "Capitano" from time to time as well.
Understood! Now, I think it's our turn to welcome these Morganas. How about we start with the greetings?
@BATTLE
The rest are... retreating? What's all this?
Cara, are you alright?
S-Something painful again, Capitano. Disregard it. I-I'm happy that we've pushed them back.

Fields.MenuText: (She's probably thinking about the whole "border troops" thing.)
If there's anything you want to talk about...
Amazing work. They'll think twice now.

Fields.DialogueText: I think I may need to do some shopping once I'm docked. I've been wanting to try some new outfits since I've come here. H-Hm... *COUGH* W-Well done, Capitano.
I implore you, Capitano. T-This is not the time. I'm happy they're running; I just hope that they have d-decency. Either way, I think I would like to go shopping when we land.
Certainly! I-I just hope that they return to fight again s-so that we may finish the job! You know... I've never been to Naples before. Do you mind if we shop once we land?
Shopping sounds like a nice idea. Maybe we can go get some souvenirs? At the same time, though, I think we should speak with the harbormaster first.
I already received word from him. Things are all right, but the garrison didn't arrive on time when they were first attacked. He would like us to check with them.
Sounds good, partner.
Haha! You were against it, and yet you say it so naturally. I think I'll take your route, though, and ask you to use Cara from time to time.
Got you. Well, I think it's time we go ahead and find out was wrong with the garrison.
Way ahead of you! Oh, before I forget: what size shoe do you wear, Capitano? I think you may need some new ones... Maybe new pants, and a hat as well. *CLICK* *BRRRT*
(She has a tape measure in her pocket!?)
So much for answers...
They gave us less of a response than the Morganas do. People depend on them to protect this place, and that can't be tolerated. I have a mind to call the podestà!

Fields.MenuText: Do you think he'd give us more of a response?
I'll see what I can do.
It wasn't their attitude, it was the look they gave us.

Fields.DialogueText: Right!? They looked at us as if we were nothing but devils! I have never seen so many bleary-eyed officers and soldiers, what's going on with them? Are they afraid of the Morganas?
Thank you, Capitano. I'm not upset at this whole thing, but I'm rather disappointed. If your harbor is under attack, you need to respond immediately, not wait until a ship may show up.
I should hope so. If he gives us the same response as the garrison did, I'm going to bring it up to... someone higher! Italia relies on us to protect them, not leave them to Morganas.
I don't know why they acted like that, but I hope that's the only time we deal with that here.
How about we go shopping then, Capitano? I don't believe those Morgana are going to come back anytime soon.
Well, I don't think it'd be a good idea to shop by yourself. After all, you can't go far from the ship, can you?
Oh, no, no, Capitano. I don't go regular shopping. I send some of the girls downstairs with measurements and directions and they shop for me. Would you mind if I gave them yours, Capitano?
That's actually a pretty ingenious way of getting around a problem. And I'll take that offer. Just so long as they're accurate. Sometimes they have a hard time getting my size down.
Don't worry about it, Capitano. I made sure to get all of your measurements down when I was on the bridge.
I will admit, you were very thorough.
I wish the soldiers would do the same. They are wearing a uniform that represents Italia in all her glory. They should act as such.
I wonder what's gotten into them? One of them said that "they'll handle it," but who's "they?"
Could they be referring to the civilians? They can't easily defend themselves!
That baffles me, too. I think that for right now, though, we've got bigger problems to worry about. It looks like they came back after all!
Phew! A-All right. Let's show them that they shouldn't have!
@BATTLE
Hmm... *THWACK* Oof. That one hit her on the nose! *THWACK* A miss. *THWACK* Yes! Take that, you horse-riding showgir--
Coming in! Excuse me, I just got off the phone with the podestà and-- Cara, what are you doing?
Playing darts. A-Ahem. What did he say, Capitano?
(Going to try to ignore the fact that that picture is taped to that board, again.) He said that he'll be sending in more backup. Apparently the Morganas got rowdy.
Why Naples, though, of all places? Hmm... What do you think, Capitano?

Fields.MenuText: The Mafia's gone, I think.
Well, it is a port. It's strategic.
There could be something hidden here.

Fields.DialogueText: Ah, yes, them. I believe Il Duce is trying to weed them out of the country to reduce crime. On the other hand, I don't know why the Morganas would care about this or that organization.
That is true. At the same time, though, this is more of a luxurious district. The Morgana wouldn't be so voracious as to attack something that has no meaning to them.
Needles in haystacks, as Americans say. Naples is rather crowded, but it'll be teeming with soldiers soon. You think they would try their luck anyway?
I guess we've been handed another mystery. It scared Vespucci badly enough to send us a letter and there were many Morganas at a specific point in the harbor. That doesn't just happen.
You're right. We have a culprit, too, but we also have no motive. What's more, the garrison's acting strange. I'll need to find some information from the locals before I start investigating.
There's plenty of them along the seaside and around here, too. We should be able to get some answers now that we have some time.
Excellent. We'll start at the beach head and work our way into port. I wager those who were closest to the port will have better answers.
So why not go to them first while it's fresh in their minds? They're close and some of them are military.
I've gotten the harbormaster and the garrison's perspective on the situation. I need to get the locals now. Don't worry, Capitano - once I get a few leads, it'll be easy to whittle it down.
Alright. We'll start at Mappatella and work our way back to the harbor, then. We'll chalk it up to us being on patrol and protecting the area.
I think the people of Naples will help us, Capitano. You see, it's all about perspectives. How many sides of the story can you get? How many assumptions can you make?
Are you sure you're not a detective?
I only work for the peace! And I will keep it, no matter what. ... Actually, I think we may need to keep the peace now.
That new radar must be working wonders. Let's get the jump on them!
@BATTLE
That was rather quick! I'm surprised by how willing everybody was to answer me...
Well, you are a Carabiniere. I'd be more surprised if people didn't greet you with cheers.
I'm not a real one, but I'm glad to play the part nonetheless. Actually, Capitano, I wanted to discuss the stories I got with you.
Testimonies, huh? Did you find anything of note?
A 42-year-old man told me he saw "odd shadows" looming over the horizon, but the military didn't do anything. He spotted it at 8:00 that morning, two hours before we arrived.
That's a telltale Morgana if I've ever seen one. What else?
A 33-year-old handyman. He said he felt chills and that the shadows were gunning straight for the port. He was incensed that there were no police around to intervene.
Hmm... Usually responses like that get some attention. Were there no other Belles nearby?
Records around that time show that they were all on different missions. Vespucci said it herself. She was worried for the right reasons. May I continue?
Of course.
24 year-old sunbathing woman. When the barrages started, she ran for a nearby office to phone the coast guard. When she talked to them, they told her to simply vacate and that they had it handled.
Another man, aged 30 and a proprietor of a nearby restaurant. He said he saw soldiers, but that they were blocked on the road by a self-made barricade by an unknown party. They had to go on foot.
Lastly, I managed to talk with a 40-year-old woman. She was widowed in the incident, and vocally lambasted the garrison for repeated incompetence. I calmed her down.

Fields.MenuText: I'm beginning to notice a pattern here...
A barricade?
Morganas getting this close to people...

Fields.DialogueText: I did too, but I wanted to make sure I wasn't rushing to judgments. Nearly every other testimony I got from that beach blamed either the garrison or the coast guard.
I saw it myself. It'd been made out of cement blocks and no cross signs. The way it was constructed, the garrison over there couldn't get vehicles around it. They were met with anger on arrival.
It's horrible, and what's worse is that people are losing faith in the people who are supposed to protect them. I can see why Vespucci might've wanted me here now. This is horrid.
Well, we've got that side, then. I think we should talk to the garrison next. They're at the harbor, aren't they?
I'll need to gather some more information in town along the way, but I think we should talk to them. I feel that barricade wasn't their own doing...
Did you ever ask who set it up?
The restaurant proprietor didn't seem to know. He only said it came up a few days before the Morganas attacked.
Something's not adding up here.
Something's afoot. And I think if we talk to the military, we'll get some answers. First things first, though. Hmph!
W-What? Did you just fire a salvo? Oh! Wait, that's a direct hit... Forgive me, I'm a bit slow on the draw.
No, no, Capitano. You're fine. I just happened to be extra focused due to getting notes. Let's get in the fight, partner!
@BATTLE
Hmmm... I got some interesting perspectives this time around, Capitano.
Well, let's hear them. Hopefully we have some explanations here.
A 26-year-old sergente told me that his squadron was notified 30 minutes after the attack started due to radio disruption. They arrived shortly after we did and took care of other forces.
What did the radio disruption sound like?
Their channels were all flooded with music and other noise. It took half an hour to get it up again. He blamed the local telecast.
So it wasn't them. If that radio went down... Maybe they could trace the signal? Either way, continue.
Right. An 18 year-old caporale. He was one of those sent to the beachhead. When he came and tried to evacuate people, some threw rocks and soda bottles at him. There were also people still bathing.
That can't be right. Everyone should've been running, and the danger was paramount. Did the raid sirens not sound?

That's my next testimony, Capitano. A 40 year-old primo caporale maggiore said that when the Morganas came, the harbormaster didn't sound the alarm. When asked, the harbormaster said it malfunctioned.
Malfunctioned? When we talked to him, he said it rang.
It did, but only after the military arrived. That brings me to my last testimony. You'll want to hear this one, Capitano.

Fields.MenuText: As if I didn't want to hear the others!
This is baffling.
So many things gone wrong...

Fields.DialogueText: Well, nobody likes hearing bad news, Capitano. I'd imagine you wouldn't like hearing it either, but at least you can hear it now. For whatever reason, they couldn't.
All the more because none of this is directly their fault. Aside from the malfunction of the equipment, that roadblock irks me. Why was it there? They couldn't get around it...
It seems uncanny, because Il Duce has ordered monthly reviews in the coastal cities. It used to be quarterly. And yet this one slipped.
Something isn't right here. What was the final testimony?
This one comes from a maresciallo, 34 years old. His squadron was the first on the harbor to mount a rescue effort. When he started the rescue and evacuated the people, he noticed something odd.
What?
There should've been ambulances and officers on the scene, but there weren't. When he tried to contact services, they said that people had flooded the streets five kilometers from the harbor.
Wait. If the alarm hadn't sounded, and the military hadn't arrived, why were all those people out in the street?
That's the thing. The maresciallo said that there was an explosion that happened at the residential district near Via Reggia di Portici.
We need to go check that place out, then.
We can't do that right now, as the area is still blocked off. But we can help with the rescue effort and give relief to the people.
Sounds like a plan. Let's move it.
Indeed... Hold that thought, Capitano. I think we have company.
Something's got to be here...
@BATTLE
When the Morganas mess with the radio, it's never so mundane. You remember reading about Lagos.
I try not to.
I'm glad the INPF sent us some emergency provisions. Handing them out has been fun, too! I love meeting all of these new people...
From the way that girl ran up to shake both of your hands, I'd say the feeling's mutual.
I think they're just happy to get some reprieve from all of this. I know the garrison was also happy to see me. They were in a much better mood today.

Fields.MenuText: I think they want you to handle PR for the time being.
Why do you think?
That one diver swam out to shake your hand.

Fields.DialogueText: Public relations are a must, but in my personal opinion, you should be with your people. I think they should've come down here and addressed everyone. This is Italia. We're a family, right?
Me? I think they were just happy to meet someone that wasn't chewing them out. The superiors up above and the people are really upset at them. Together, though, we're strong. Italia is a family.
He walked right out of the ocean to say hello! It was like coming home to a family. Even if... even if that family's fallen on hard times.
Families sometimes go through rough patches, Cara. This is just one of them.
I understand that, but this venomous virtriol towards each other isn't helping anything. Equipment was failing, people tried their best...
It's different with every person, but sometimes your best isn't good enough. It also comes with how you present yourself. You're a lady of the people, Cara. They aren't.
What I'm saying is that they can be. When a nation believes in its army and an army believes in the people they're supposed to protect, they're strong! I just... don't understand.
I think a lot of people support Il Duce here, but a lot of people don't.
Why wouldn't they support him? I m-may not always agree with his methods, but he's nonetheless a powerful leader. Italia feels strong again!
It does feel strong, but strength through domination comes with a price.
What do you mean, Capitano?
A military is only as strong as its people are. Do the people you talked to feel strong?
... A-Ahem. I've heard some stories passed around from people here. I-I... Can we talk about this in private, partner?
Of course, Cara. I'm sorry if I made you uncomfortable--
No, no! Not at all, Capitano. There's been something on my mind, but I'd rather not talk about it today. Maybe later...
I understand. When you are ready, we can talk about it then. I promise.
Haha... You certainly know how to be reassuring. A good partner if I've ever known one, but I haven't really known a partner like you... Ah. Capitano?
Don't worry, I saw it. Let's approach it quietly this time. And, thank you, Cara. You're a wonderful partner.
@BATTLE
Hmm... What would big sis do in this situation? Would she... Maybe she'd just pull herself up, puff some smoke, and face it?
Cara? Are you in here? I've been looking for you.
Oh, I'm sorry, Capitano. I just wanted some time to myself. The operation's in the local enforcement's hands, and they're going to increase their presence around port.
Indeed, and from what I heard, Il Duce is sending some more provisions as a sign of good will.
He did!? Ah, thank the lord. Hopefully this eases everyone out. I saw a soldier playing cards with an old man yesterday.
Like I said, times come and go like waves. It's all in how you view it. Perspectives, right?
Yes, yes. I just... Hm. The sea's choppy today. I feel it on my rudder.

Fields.MenuText: The rudder of your mind?
Would you like some mints? They help with nausea.
Would you like me to read to you?

Fields.DialogueText: Did you get any new books from the marina? I heard there's a bookstore over there. I wanted to visit it after we finished here. No thank you, though, Capitano. I just need to breathe. I'm sorry.
I would appreciate one. I... think the fog's going to roll in later tonight. I'd honestly care for rain at this point. It'd help me out a bit. I'm sorry, Capitano.
Now that's a metaphor I didn't think of... I need to write that down. I'm... Capitano, I'm a bit in my own head at the moment. The sea being a bit choppy isn't helping. I'm... sorry.
You don't need to apologize, Cara. Having battles in your mind is just as important as having them outside.
I've just... I've only dealt with these things a few times. I shouldn't say "dealt..." Maybe I just distracted myself with something else. I don't know.
You're just in a fog, Cara. It happens. Was it something you saw today?
No, it wasn't just today. It was the other day. All of those people, just so mad at each other. Hate, regret, and tearing down people you loved. I... I worry, Capitano.
Cara, I promise you, you aren't like that. Any problem that you have, you can say it to me. You're seeing the world at its worst. Some waves are harder to climb. But you know what?
What, Capitano?
I've said before that it takes time. It also takes compassion and understanding. You have so much love to give, and the people love you. Always remember: you're a person first and a ship second.
Capitano... I... I don't know what to say. Big sis has been the only one to be this... legitimate with me. I-- W-Woah!
Huph! *CATCH* Got you this time. It looks like we've got company again.
Of all the times! Ah, well. That's life for you. ... Say, Capitano? After this, can we just sit in your quarters and drink some tea together? I... feel I could use some.
Of course, Cara.
@BATTLE
Well, this block has seen better days.
An explosion like this... Hm. Do you think we can have a look around, Capitano?
I already let them know that we were coming. When they heard your name, they automatically said yes.
I knew they liked me, but I didn't think they'd like me that much!

Fields.MenuText: Don't sell yourself short.
Aren't the Carabinieri celebrated?
They'd invite you over for tea.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm not! I just didn't think we'd receive this type of welcome after the garrison was so unfriendly when we came in. They wouldn't even look at me! It just seems odd.
They are, and they should be! I only bear their namesake, but I know that the Carabinieri are also in a league of their own. They're essentially another police unit, but even then... this is odd.
Maybe some sherry. I'd appreciate that along with some jazz, if it isn't too much to ask. Warm welcomes out of the way, this is kind of odd.
It is strange, isn't it?
Strange or not, we have some work to do. Let's start with the explosion area itself. I think there should be some tipoffs to what caused it around here.
The soldiers I talked to said they believe it was caused by a boiler explosion.
Hm... There's a lot of debris around this opening in particular. Where did they say the explosion happened? Or, how did it start?
They said that they think the boiler being old started it. Others are saying that they think it was the furnace upstairs that caught fire.
That's quite odd, Capitano. Look at this over here - do you notice anything about this doorway?
The door looks fairly worn... but no different from the others.
Exactly, and this doorway here leads into the boiler room. The door itself isn't burnt, chipped, or bent. Now, if I open the door... The boiler looks like it exploded, but look closer!
Well, what do you know? The bottom half of it is completely fine. What about the furnace?
Capitano, it's summer, and we're in a coastal city. The furnace would be turned off. So if no power's running to the furnace, and the boiler was damaged in the explosion...
Then neither of them are to blame, but what about gas?
A good point, but the gas pipes were immediately shut off after the explosion. This complex has a failsafe system. What's more, no one was using their ovens at the time of the explosion, either.
Then that means...
Precisely, partner. The boiler, nor the furnace, or the gas caused the explosion. So, that leaves us with a big question: What caused the explosion?
*FWOOOSH* *KABLAM*
Ah! Do you see that down there? They hit that phonebox dead on! They can aim this far!?
Well, I certainly know what caused *that* explosion. Let's roll.
@BATTLE
So we've got some facts that we know about now, Capitano. The explosion wasn't caused by any of the reasons the military listed. When I told them about it, they were surprised.
Remind me again why the police or the fire department didn't investigate first?
The military was on standby, and it took rescue crews a while to get there, anyway. As for the firemen, they were busy upstream near Mugnano di Napoli. Some riots were going on.
And with the radio transmissions seemingly out... Okay, that checks out. So then, how did the explosion happen?
Well, Capitano. After we took care of the Morganas that day, I managed to go back to the apartment. You see, I found something else while I was in there and managed to snap a few pictures. Here!

Fields.MenuText: Since when do you have a camera?
Smells like lavender...
Taking your own crime scene photos, huh?

Fields.DialogueText: I had the ladies buy one for me when they were out. I bought it for other things, too, but I'm using it for this right now. What do you notice in these photos?
O-Oh! I'm so sorry, Capitano. I'm trying out a new soap. I washed my hands three times after getting these developed so that they wouldn't smell like the engine room. Anyway, do you see anything?
A detective has to take some images for later use. Maybe I need to doodle in my notebook more, but this works well for the time being. So! Anything in these photos strike you as odd?
A lot of photos... Oh, this of the boiler room! Looks like that explosion took out that part of the building too, but the other part of it is still standing.
Yep! The top part of the boiler is also missing, but here's something else I noticed. Look at this photo here.
It's a piece of wood... Wait a second, that's not just any piece of wood! It's got part of the Tridentina on it!
Corretta! I found others just like it, too. When I went upstairs where the explosion first happened, I found the room where the explosion point was. It was right above the boiler room!
You're not seriously suggesting that it was caused by munitions?
That isn't the most damning piece of evidence, partner. This picture, right here. I found the remains of two of these lying around. Copper wire!
And that room had a window, didn't it? Facing the street, too?
You're getting me now, Capitano. This explosion wasn't an accident. Someone planted a bomb in between a bunch of munitions and then blew it up while the Morganas made their landing...
That's a lot of military-grade equipment. The copper wire could be as far as half a mile away to a detonator, too. There's also the radio jammings and the roadblocks... Something isn't adding up.

Glad you're seeing it now, Capitano. The bottom half of the boiler is still there too, meaning the explosion took place just above. Those radio disruptions and the roadblock seem way too convenient...
Do you think that somebody set up the roadblock, jammed the radio transmissions, and caused this explosion so that the Morganas would have an easier time landing? That's what I'm guessing.
I don't think it's somebody, Capitano. I think it's a group. Think about it: how would someone be able to go all the way to the beachhead and set up a roadblock, then come back over here?
And how would someone get these munitions into a building like this? How would someone be able to jam the radios for that long?
I think I may have an answer for--
Huh..? An emergency transmission. Cara, we've got trouble near Mercato...
Let's not dilly-dally. I'm ready to play the vanguard! Though... we should look at those photos again when we get back.
@BATTLE
Out of my way, you sea hags!
Looks like we interrupted them just as the going was getting good!
Capitano, I'm going closer! Over there, that cafe's in trouble!
Looks like the military's here this time, but they can't get to it. Those people are trapped inside...
Not on my watch, they aren't. I'm going full speed and breaking that line.

Fields.MenuText: Be careful, Cara.
If we do that, we might get caught in the crossfire...
Hell yes. Let's do it.

Fields.DialogueText: I promise you, Capitano. I'm not going to let anything happen to you while you're on deck. Hold on tight, if you can. If I can ram them, they may be stunned long enough for potshots!
Don't worry, Capitano. They know we're here and they'll aim away from us. Even so, I'll make sure you're protected too, but we've got to get to those people!
Don't mention hell to me! The lord wouldn't look too kindly on that, but I get the meaning. Let's get in there, get them, and then get these witches out! I'm with you, partner!
I trust you, Cara! Ramming speed!
Une, due, tre, quattro, how many of you do I have to get past!?
Damn, what's your hull made out of?
An iron will, Capitano! Ugh!
Nihihihihihi... Souls...
The only thing you're going to feed on are my salvos! Take 'em all!
@BATTLE
That bought us just enough time to get close...
Alright, let's get them out of there, Capitano!
This is the Captain of the Soldati-Carabinieri! Women and children out first! Stay near Carabinieri and get to the military checkpoint! We'll cover you!
"It's the meritous ship!" "Thank you, thank you!" "M-My leg..." "Come on, I'll help you!" "The Carabinieri have come to rescue us!" *CHEERING, SCREAMS*
Even when things are hitting the fan, you're still popular, Cara.
Hahaha... Oh, I-I mean... Meritous... And-- Hm! We aren't out of the woods yet, though. They're trying to get past us...
The keyword here is "trying." How about we show them how to quit?
I still can't believe all of that happened just a few days ago. I haven't been in a firefight that intense since I met you, Capitano.
Those Morganas really want something in Naples, or they're really persistent. Either way, it looks like we got a faster response this time, too.
I'm glad the military showed up, too. Between us all we saved at least forty people!

Fields.MenuText: Hopefully that cools tensions around here.
They got really close this time...
You were like a legendary hero, Cara.

Fields.DialogueText: I hope so, too. They were really trying to get people out of there and help us out. Did you see that mortar man? He could hit a fly in the air. I'm so proud to see us working in arms together...
I'll say! That one Morgana who got up right close to me had the nerve to sneer. She wasn't laughing when I showed her how my guns work. Serves her right.
Ahaha! I-It was all in a day's work, Capitano. I'm just glad I can help Italia in any way I can, and yesterday I did something big; but I didn't do it alone! I hope those soldiers are all right.
Hopefully the unity lasts. War can tear people apart, but it can also unite.
I hope so, too. They were really happy after we got rid of the Morganas!
Speaking of which, did their radios not cut out this time?
No, actually, and that reminds me, too. I managed to send a telegram to the communications offices. I got an interesting response. The radio equipment wasn't malfunctioning. It was jammed.
Jammed? ... Cara, are you thinking what I'm thinking?
Indeed, Capitano. This was definitely a conspiracy. That roadblock, too. I think it was constructed first, and probably took four people to build. I actually talked to the investigators, too.
The investigators at the building explosion?
Yes, I shared my evidence with them. They confirmed our suspicions, but here's something else. For an explosion of that size, the person inside would've needed at least three crates of explosives.
So a group builds the roadblock, another group transfers crates into an apartment complex - later detonating a payload - and then a third group jams the radios. A perfect diversion.
It's almost too perfect. Going by what the restuarant owner said, that roadblock was up nearly a week before the attack. No records of construction in the city hall.
No records..? Then who built it? It couldn't have been the military...
They didn't build it either, and when they examined the roadblock, they noticed that the signs were actually from the Great War.
A fake, then? Somebody set that up knowing that the military stationed over there couldn't get past it right away.
That's not all. A military shipment to Livorno was scheduled a day before that. Four crates of explosive ammunition were unaccounted for at leaving time, despite being accounted for initially.
And let me guess, those crate numbers were--
According to the forensics, yes. Now all I have to do is figure out who that apartment belonged to.
We can do that later. Right now, we've got some problems. The bridge is signaling distress--
Well, let's get them out of it!
@BATTLE
Alright, Capitano. I just got the information I needed sent over from the apartment complex.
Excellent. So who owned that apartment?
It actually belonged to somebody I met before. That 33-year-old handyman: Carlo Guerriero.
And what was Signore Guerriero doing on the day of the attack?
According to his testimony, he was in a shop in Borgo Orefici fixing a broken pipe. When he heard the commotion, he ran out of the store to see what was going on, and that's when the attack started.
Santa Lucia? ... Something sounds familiar about that.
Indeed. It happens to be near the beach head and can lead onto the main road of Via Ammiraglio.
But that also heads to the harbor...
I know what you're thinking, Capitano. I made sure to look at any other history he may have had. There's no criminal record on him, but he is well known around town for being a fixer.
I see that, but if he was at that place at the time, he could've had both a view of the beach and of the harbor if he was in the right spot. Even if he has no history, that's still suspicious.
That's what irked me, too. Luckily, the apartment complex also provided me with a detail. Carlo was having his room fumigated for pests. All of his possessions were at a nearby warehouse.

Fields.MenuText: The only pest here is the culprit.
Who has the money to store their stuff in a warehouse?
Anything else in that warehouse we need to know about?

Fields.DialogueText: Hahahaha! That's a good one, Capitano, I'll have to write that one down. But I like the way you're thinking. You're on my trail now, too.
I'll answer that next, but I want to tell you: I'm really impressed with your deduction, Capitano. It feels like you and I are really in this together!
I'll have an itemized list for you as soon as possible - and it will include a 320mm gun, believe it or not.
The pleasure's mine, but how could Carlo store all of his things in a warehouse? Doesn't that cost some figures?
Less than you'd think, but here's the kicker. Carlo has connections. There was another person who signed on the storage.
Oho! And who's our second player in this game?
28 year-old Flaviano D'Amore. He used to be a disc jockey, but now he works as an electrician. He lives around the apartment complex as well.
Used to be a disc jockey, huh? You wager he knows anything about radios?
I'd say he knows a lot.
Well, it looks like we--
Ah! Capitano, Carabineri! Sorry for bursting in, but we spotted a group of Morganas down the coast!
(The Captain and Carabinieri wink to one another.)
@BATTLE
You're kidding.
No. It's apparently in disgraceful condition, mind you. Even so...
That's one hell of a warehouse. How could Carlo afford to store all of his things there in the first place? That's got to cost a mint.
We've got two players in the game so far, but we need to make sure. Where was Flaviano on the day of the attack?
He was spotted running in the direction of the apartment after the attack started, actually.
Caught red-handed.
You'd think, but other witnesses around the area knew him, too. They said he went past the apartment.
Where did he end up?
At the former radio station, of course.
Were there any transmissions coming from there at the time?
Nothing except music, of course. When I talked to the radio station, however, they told me that the electrician had come in to check on a few things in the booth.
And just after the attack when the radio reports would've been coming in...
Exactly. Two players, Capitano. We still have some unanswered questions, though. Who was the triggerman at the apartment? Who built the roadblock? Who stole the munitions and put them there?

Fields.MenuText: It feels like every problem we solve just leads to more.
Ok, now I'm getting excited.
We just got into the spiderweb.

Fields.DialogueText: That's the fun of solving a case, Capitano. At least, in my opinion it's fun. Even when you feel like you know everything, there's still layers about... That's the best part of it all.
I am, too. It's hard not to jump around in my seat as I tell you what I found. Big sis would yell at me if she saw me like this, but I don't care. There's so much to be solved!
I feel like I'm buzzing about in it like a honeybee. Unlike the honeybee, though, this girl's got more than one sting in her. And when I'm doing this with you, partner... Oooh! I'm so giddy.
I feel like we're getting closer. What's the story with Carlo and Flaviano? Do they know each other?
They've been friends for a long while according to locals. Flaviano's also got a brother, too. You'll never guess who he is.
A military man?
Correta! A primo tenente, no less. 30 year old Giuseppe D'Amore. When I asked the military about him, they told me he works as both a Primo Tenente and also helps with shipments.
Shipments, huh? He wouldn't happen to have been there when the munitions went missing, was he?
Sharp, Capitano. He was there as an auxiliary unit. Here's something else, though. Giuseppe let an unauthorized military vehicle in the premise to make a delivery: a post van.
Looks like he got a special parcel.
And-- Hm! I think we've just recieved one, too.
Look at what came in the mail...
@BATTLE
As I was saying... Giuseppe was there as an auxiliary unit. Here's something else, though. Giuseppe let an unauthorized military vehicle through to make a delivery: a post van.
Oh, we've got them now. And when were the four crates unaccounted for?
At 2:35 PM, nearly half an hour after the post van arrived. The post van had also left around 2:20. To heft a crate that heavy would've required the help of some equipment...
Which the postman almost certainly had, because those packages are *heavy.* And, who was our postman?
Postwoman. Marcella Ferri, Age 27. She also happens to have been dating Giuseppe for the last 3 years, according to the post staff.
Ah, I see what's going on here. Giuseppe lets her in, and because they know he has a girlfriend, they don't think it's suspicious when they go off by their lonesome for, say, 20 minutes?
20 minutes too long-- Hm! Capitano, you may want to brace yourself...
For what? I don't-- Oh, I just felt it, too.
@BATTLE
Well, that was annoying. Care for some tea, Cara?
Of course, Capitano. Mmm- Thank you. Did you pick some up while you were in town?
I told the mess that you preferred it, and now they put it on the menu.
C-Capitano, you didn't have to do that for me! I could've told them!

Fields.MenuText: Hey, you know what I like.
It's nothing, really.
You could have, but you didn't.

Fields.DialogueText: I do, but... Ah, Capitano. I'm always so mixed about receiving such generosity like this. I prefer to work for the reward, not just receive it, you know? I-I'm grateful that you did, however...
Nothing!? Capitano, you've given me something so great that I think I could fall over! I just... I wish I could do something for you, you know? I like putting in effort, too...
... I'm impressed that you can make it sound like I was remiss in my duties because I didn't ask for special favors.
Sometimes you've got to treat yourself, Cara. And sometimes people will give you things without things in return. You give your love to the people and don't expect anything. Generosity!
I love the people, Capitano. I'm here to protect them. They don't have to do anything for me. But if it's you, Capitano, you're my partner! I've always got to have your back!
And I'll always have yours, Cara, but you deserve to be treated. I don't know what your older sister or those other Belles may have said, but you do!
T-Thank you, Capitano.
It's a gift I have.
Can you return it?
Capitano, we've got one of them! Carlo, to be exact.
Carlo? Did he turn himself in?
No, no. After I gave my evidence to the military, they started searching for him. They found him at the barricade!
One down, three to go. Did they get any information?
Well, they've chosen to officially deputize us. So if we find any of the conspirators, we can bring them in too. Carlo said that he was out there to take it down at the request of the proprietor.
I assume they didn't buy that?
Not with a 1-count lira... They even found some things on him. A pair of binoculars for one, and a note, too.
Let me guess. That note was instructions on what to do to tear down the barricade?
No, but you're close. It was an envelope that contained lira, and it was meant for the restaurant owner.
A fifth accomplice!?
I was surprised to hear of it, too, but the restaurant proprietor also had a two-way radio. The frequency? It's a private channel that Flaviano set up.
And so that's why he ran past the apartment, because the proprietor saw the Morgana coming... Well, that basically confirms it now. What about the others?
Marcella was arrested earlier, too. They found from several people that the license plate of the mail van she drove matched the one that later delivered multiple "boxes" to Carlo's apartment.

Fields.MenuText: You can run, but you can't hide from the law.
Cara, you're a genius sleuth.
We're about to wrap it up...

Fields.DialogueText: No you can't! Even if you somehow manage to escape, the devil waits for special people so that he can fork them when they get there. Ah, Capitano, this is wonderful!
Ahaha... Capitano, thank you... At first I thought it was going to be rougher than rough. When you helped me along, though, I couldn't give in! Ahah, and now we're here!
I can feel my fingers on the bow, Capitano. All we need to do now is just tie the ribbons... I can't believe we've made it this far. Now all we have to do is remain vigillant!
Couldn't have gotten here without you, Cara. I honestly never expected I'd be solving a big mystery like this.
Ahaha... Capitano, hearing you say that is giving me a big head rush. I'm still not used to this whole complimenting thing, I'm sorry. I couldn't have done it without you, either!
Of course, Cara. We're partners. We've got each other's backs.
You've got that right! Now that we've got our evidence, it's time to round up those responsible.
Agreed. If we're deputized, that means there's nothing stopping us now other than the Morganas!
I think they're trying to stop us now, actually... I'll show them that they can't!
@BATTLE
Hmhm~ Ah, I can't wait to dig in... I know Belles don't have to eat, but sometimes I just want to, you know?

Fields.MenuText: Can't remember the last time I ate an orange.
Is it like that with drinks, too?
Could go for a lot of things, right now.

Fields.DialogueText: You're losing your vitamin C, Capitano! Maybe we should stop by Sicily on our way back after this is all over. They make the best oranges over there! Corsaca talks about them all the time.
Hm, I find myself craving tea more than I should. I do enjoy a nice refreshing cola, from time to time. Corsaca introduced me to a wonderful drink from her hometown... I wish I remembered the name.
Like what, Capitano? For me, I'm in the mood for some bourbon. Maybe I could do with some gaunchale as well? Corsaca likes caccio e pepe the most. She's often told me it reminds her of home.
I've been meaning to ask about Corsaca. Has she been a friend of yours for a long time?
Corsaca was one of the first to join my crew, actually. She comes from Roma, and if I'm not mistaken her father fought in the Great War. It's only natural that she'd become a military lady.
Interesting. So she was there when you were built?
She was stationed there at the time, and she's been with me ever since. Hard to believe it's been two years already...
You're telling me... And now we're in the middle of this.
Time's a flat circle as far as I'm concerned. I just hope after this we can all go have a little bit of fun. Duty comes first, but you should relax yourself too.
That's why you treasure the moments we've got now. Speaking of which...
Hmhm! Thank you very much! *Sip* Ah... It's so refreshingly good. Stuff like this almost makes you forget you're out at sea.
I will admit, having this kind of stuff is rather nice. Say, you said Corsaca's from Rome, right? What brought her out here, anyway?
You know, I can answer that myself!
Corsaca! Come here, we're about to enjoy lunch. Is there anything you really want?
I think I'll have what you're having. I've always wanted to try out that tea you favor, Cara. And, yes, Capitano, I'm from Rome.
So, what brought you to Cara, exactly? Adventure? Sea breezes?
A little bit of both, though I can't deny I came here because of my old man.
He was a soldier, wasn't he?
Officer, and he ran his squad like he did our family; compassionate, but a bit of a hardass.
Sounds a lot like Nera.
Snnnrrrrrkkkkk... C-Capitano, d-don't say that about... Snnrrkkk... Ahahahahahahaha!
You heard about Nera, too, huh? She's a bit of a chain smoker and probably has a whip underneath there, but she's effective.
Well, she does have a repu--
Owch! Cara, did you just rock the ship?
T-That wasn't me! We're under attack!
Ah well, we'll get done with it in time for dinner.
@BATTLE
Capitano, I've got a telegram from the OVRA.
They're involved in this, too? Il Duce must really not like the mess.
If Naples was threatened, it's a matter of national security, which I very much agree with. Italia will not stand for that!

Fields.MenuText: I know that serious face of yours...
I wasn't expecting this...
Glad to see we've reached an understanding.

Fields.DialogueText: O-Oh, I'm sorry, Capitano, did I make a face? Urgh, I'm still not used to working hand-in-hand with intelligence like this. Big sis would always tell me to be reverent. Even if she didn't, I would be!
Neither was I.This trust they've put in us is making me rigid. I will stand proud and solve this for Italia!
Isn't it, though!? I for one will not be squandering this task. Il Duce is trusting us and I'll do my best! E-Ergh, I'm sorry, Capitano, this is sort of a rare thing... I don't want to blow it...
I'll be right here with you, Cara. The OVRA being with us is just another piece of the puzzle. Speaking of, what's the telegram about?
It's about Giuseppe. Intelligence has confirmed that Carlo, Marcella, and Flaviano are in custody, but that Giuseppe and at least five other people are still at large.
So Giuseppe is the mastermind? How did a mortar man and what basically equates to a captain get this far?
Carlo did most of the logistics, but Giuseppe had the idea. As to what his reasons are, we won't know unless we catch him, and Naples is blocked off from all sides. He's got nowhere to go.
I think I may have at least a possible motive. Do you remember that the people on the beachhead blamed military incompetence?
I do... Was that part of the idea, too? Did he also know that this area was unprotected by a Belle? If he did that, it would've made the people distrust the military more, and without a Belle...
Naples would be easy pickings for Morganas, but why hand over Italy to them?
According to intelligence... Giuseppe was a nationalist at heart, a man with much pride for his country and military. It doesn't make sense to me for him to be working with the Morganas... and yet...
If he did it specifically to attract them, he definitely knows a few things that are above his grade.
It makes me fume just thinking about it, and the worst part is that we have no idea where he could be...
Maybe not you two, but I do.
Corsaca! D-Did you find something out?
Info from the mainland. There's going to be a demonstration of people who are upset at the military's response of the attack. It's taking place at the harbor tomorrow.
I'm the only Belle here, and our fleet is...
Currently restocking at the harbor, too. It'll take them a while to move. Looks like Giuseppe has one last trick to play. That many people at the harbor will make prime targets for the Morganas.
Capitano, I have reason to suspect that Giuseppe and his accomplices will be nearby. I managed to tap into the frequency from the radio station that Carlo used. Giuseppe is still using it.
We'll be able to track them, but how are we going to save all of those people?
Grr! Not again... Those Morganas are here. We'll have to think later, for now we've got company...
Roger that. Corsaca, hold on tight.
@BATTLE
Capitano, tapping's been successful thanks to Corsaca. Now we know exactly what they're intending to do.
And what's that? I can already see the people gathering about...
They were going to use the distraction of the crowd like you said. They also said that if we showed up, we'd be easily overwhelmed enough for them to infiltrate me.

Fields.MenuText: Really? Doing that to a lady?
As if we'd let them.
Not if our new recruits have anything to say about it.

Fields.DialogueText: It's really horrible, and these clowns deserve exactly what they're going to get once we're through with them. I think the show's about to start...
I want them to come in. It'll make catching them much easier. I'm about ready for a challenge, too. Oh, dear. It looks like the crowd's gathering. Are you ready, Capitano?
It seems we can't put ashore without finding eager fighters. It's a good problem to have.
I'm ready when you are, Cara. Even if we didn't have that intelligence from Corsica, I think we could've figured it out.
Ahaha! I'll have to recommend her for promotion. She'd make a great intelligence officer... Hm. All right, Capitano, things are getting good... Hm! There's a couple of Morganas incoming.
All right, then. You remember the plan from yesterday?
Sure do. We make a ruckus, Giuseppe and his goons board us, try to make their way to you, and then that's when I ambush them. I've only played surprise attacks on Morganas, but--
Hold that thought. Incoming Morgana, there's a lot of them. Get ready, partner. We're about to go full Dick Tracy.
Hehe! If you're Tracy, I'm Poirot, because we're both detectives now, partner. Come on, sea witches! Face me!
@BATTLE
Sad like tongue depressors. Was that really all they had?
I wager a second wave will come soon. Hm? Oh! Now I'm certain that even without Corsaca, I would've noticed a boarding as loud as that.
Should I sound the alarm?
Go ahead, Capitano. They're on me now, and they aren't getting out.
With pleasure.
Hehehehehe... I can see why big sis can be such a tease sometimes. That did the trick, Capitano - they're panicking!
Captain to main staff, track down the intruders. If you should find Giuseppe, radio me immediately.
Capitano! This is Corsaca - four of them have already been detained! One of them chickened out...
What about Giuseppe?
He's making for the deck, according to the others. They had a whole bunch of explosives on them...
Trying to blow me up? That's downright cruel, because... I'm about to make this grand plan go up in smoke.
Oh? That's him! Capitano, he just ran out of the door onto the main deck!
Don't let him get away! We're close now!
Hm... Looks like we've got more conspirators, Capitano.
Trying to bail him out? Fat chance.
I think it's time for the closing act. And I know just how to pull down the curtain!
@BATTLE
That was a bit rough, but it looks like we're good. Excellent work, Cara.
Thank you, Capitano, but now we've got one last loose end. Hmhm. Well, well, well... I didn't think I'd be welcoming a traitor aboard.

Fields.MenuText: Didn't we do that already?
You never know...
How about we show him some hospitality?

Fields.DialogueText: Henri wasn't a traitor. He was a man forced to choose his country over the woman he loved, and he chose her. This one, however, only chose this avenue for himself. A traitor.
There's a lot of things we don't know, Capitano. At the same time, I say that the truth will set you free, no matter what. I think it's high time we found the truth ourselves.
We've already been such gracious hosts to the Morganas. I can't imagine not offering the same to this traitor. After all, Italia prides herself on being welcoming and offering good cheer.
(You've got that right.) Alright, Giuseppe, there's nowhere left to run. All the Morgana are gone and we're too far out.
You've done such a low thing, trying to pit brother against brother and selling your own country and honor out. Shame on you.
Damn the both of you... Can't you see what we're trying to accomplish!? Italia is strong, but its leaders are weak! The people will have no fight left in them if this continues!
Are you that far gone to not believe in your fellow man? The fact that you still wear your uniform is pathetic. We've got you, so just give it up and come quietly, you traitorous dog.
Screw that! *CLICK* The hell with you. I'm at least taking out the Capitano before I go!
(Ah! Shit!)
Oh, please. Huph! *CRACK*
Agh! A whip!? D-Damn it...
Huph! *CLINK CLINK* Bad dogs get the leash.
Guh... You... You morons... Italia could've gone back to the days of Roma with the Morganas... Il Duce's only one man now, but he'll be many in the future... You fools... You... utter... fools...
You betrayed your country and had the audacity to point a pistol at *my* capitano. I'm placing you under arrest for high treason and terrorism, Giuseppe D'Amore.
Cara... You saved me! Ah, and here I thought that whip was for show!
It has its uses, Capitano. And, don't mention it. We're partners; more than that, we're friends. By God's grace, I'll be there for you and you'll be there for me.
So that was it, huh? He hated the direction Italy was going in, he saw the Morganas, thought they were here to make humanity better, and put all of this together?
More or less, all of them were pretty much going for the same thing. Giuseppe knew about the Belles and Morganas thanks to corruption, and he also knew that Vespucci was leaving.
Vespucci... Ah, I really owe her one. Though there's one thing I don't get: what made him think that the Morganas were a better deal?
I'm not empathizing with him, nor am I stating my opinion on Il Duce, but war isn't good for anyone. Abroad or at home.
... You're right on that, Capitano. I wish... I wish things were different in Italia now, too. There are some times I wonder... if I'm even doing the right thing?

Fields.MenuText: You don't have to wonder. I know you are.
Do right by yourself, Cara.
Was saving me the right thing to do?

Fields.DialogueText: C-Capitano! ... Yes, I'm sure it was. I *know* it was. I would've taken that bullet for you if he'd fired. It wouldn't have hurt me much, but I would've done it. That's who I am!
Right by myself? Hah. I don't even know who I really am yet, Capitano. Then again, when it comes down to it, that's what finding the truth is about. It won't always be solved quickly...
C-Capitano? ... Thank you. You saying that to me makes me feel like even if I don't know things now, I'll be all right. I guess... Like the mysteries we chase, life is one big guessing game.
Confidence is key, but acknowledging your feelings, good or bad, helps you understand yourself. Don't hide from them. When you're the master of your emotions, you'll be that much sharper.
Emotions... Hm. Capitano, I think it's going to take a long time for that. I fear that showing my emotions may be improper.
They're not. Emotions are normal, and if anyone on this ship says otherwise, they're wrong. It won't be tomorrow, or maybe in the next year, but Cara, I know you can do it.
Capitano, thank you so much... I wish I could-- Hm? Is that the telegram machine?
It is, as a matter of fact. Let me see what we've got. ... Cara, you're not going to believe this. It's a letter from Il Duce!
I-Il Duce!? L-Let me see!
"To the esteemed Captain of the Carabiniere and the ship itself. You have my utmost gratitude for solving the issue in Naples with great care, cooperation, and duty."
"You have done Italia a service beyond compare, and your actions have stopped an utter calamity. For that, I intend to present Carabiniere with the Military Order of Savoy, for showing such valor..."
Cara... I don't know what to say.
I think I do, Capitano. *Sniff* Even if we didn't get this congratulations... I-I would still be happy. J-Just now I'm...
Cara... Are you crying?
Y-You told me to be honest with my emotions, Capitano. *Sniff* A-And I am.
Come here.
Ahahahahaha! A-Augh, Capitano, I'm tired, but I'm... *Sniff*
Let's go get some tea and ice cream. I think it's well deserved.
Hah... Is that before or after our guest leaves?
Guest, what-- Oh. I didn't even notice the radar.
Always be observant, partner. N-Now, let's get at them together!
